definitions: break or cause to break suddenly into parts or fragments often with force
damage or weaken the unity or strength of something like relationships or systems
examples: The impact fractured his leg bone in three places
She fractured the glass by dropping it on concrete
Political disagreements began to fracture the party's unity
The scandal fractured trust between business partners completely

definitions: break or cause to break into small parts or incomplete pieces
examples: The ancient pottery fragmented when archaeologists tried to move it
Years of weather fragmented the old stone wall completely

definitions: place an official mark on mail to show postage has been paid
examples: The postal worker franked all the letters before dispatching them
Government offices can frank official mail without using stamps

definitions: unravel or wear away at the edges of fabric or rope through use
cause strain or irritation to nerves relationships or tempers over time
examples: The rope began to fray after months of outdoor use
Her favorite sweater frayed at the cuffs and collar
Constant arguments frayed their patience with each other
The long wait frayed everyone's nerves at the airport

definitions: work for different companies at different times rather than being permanently employed by one
examples: She decided to freelance as a graphic designer after graduation
Many journalists freelance for multiple publications to earn more income

definitions: transport goods in bulk by truck train ship or aircraft
examples: The company freights electronics from Asia to North America weekly
They freight fresh produce across the country using refrigerated trucks

definitions: be constantly or visibly worried or anxious about something
gradually wear away or corrode through persistent rubbing or gnawing
examples: She fretted about her exam results for weeks afterwards
Parents often fret when their children are late coming home
The river fretted away the bank over many years
Constant use had fretted the rope until it broke

definitions: make someone afraid or anxious by threatening or surprising them
examples: The loud thunder frightened the small children during the storm
Horror movies are designed to frighten audiences for entertainment

definitions: form a border or edge around something decoratively or naturally
examples: Tall trees fringe the lake creating a natural boundary
Decorative tassels fringe the edge of the expensive curtains

definitions: search someone for concealed weapons or goods by running hands over their clothing
move around in a playful lively or energetic way
examples: Security guards frisked everyone entering the courthouse for weapons
The police officer frisked the suspect before making an arrest
The puppies frisked around the garden chasing butterflies joyfully
Young lambs frisk in the meadow on sunny spring mornings

definitions: play and move about cheerfully excitedly or energetically
examples: Children frolicked in the waves during their beach vacation
The dolphins frolicked alongside the boat delighting all the tourists

definitions: cover with frost or become covered with frost from freezing temperatures
cover a cake with icing or frosting for decoration
examples: The cold night frosted the car windows making them opaque
Early morning temperatures frosted the grass with white crystals
She frosted the birthday cake with chocolate buttercream icing
The baker frosted dozens of cupcakes for the wedding reception

definitions: produce or cause to produce a mass of small bubbles or foam
examples: The cappuccino machine frothed the milk to creamy perfection
Waves frothed against the rocky shore during the storm

definitions: prevent a plan or attempted action from progressing succeeding or being fulfilled
cause someone to feel upset or annoyed as a result of being unable to achieve something
examples: Bad weather frustrated their plans for an outdoor wedding
Technical problems frustrated attempts to launch the new website
The complicated instructions frustrated everyone trying to assemble the furniture
Traffic jams frustrate commuters trying to get to work on time

definitions: cook food in hot fat or oil typically in a shallow pan
examples: She fried eggs and bacon for breakfast every Sunday morning
The restaurant fries their fish in a light crispy batter

definitions: present or deal with something in a vague or inadequate way especially to mislead
examples: Politicians often fudge their answers to avoid making firm commitments
The company fudged the numbers to make profits look better

definitions: carry out complete or satisfy a duty promise requirement or condition
examples: She worked hard to fulfil her dream of becoming a doctor
The company must fulfil all safety requirements before opening

definitions: carry out complete or satisfy a duty promise requirement or condition
examples: He fulfilled his promise to visit his grandmother every week
The new employee fulfilled all expectations in her first month

definitions: use hands clumsily while doing or handling something
examples: She fumbled with her keys trying to unlock the door in darkness
The nervous student fumbled through his presentation notes

definitions: emit gas smoke or vapor especially in a harmful or unpleasant way
feel show or express great anger or irritation
examples: The chemical factory fumed toxic gases into the atmosphere
The old car fumed black smoke from its exhaust pipe
She fumed silently when her ideas were dismissed without consideration
He fumed about the unfair treatment for days afterwards

definitions: seek financial support for a charity cause or other enterprise
examples: The school fundraised for new playground equipment through various events
They fundraise annually to support local homeless shelters

definitions: avoid something out of fear or anxiety especially a responsibility
examples: He funked the difficult conversation with his boss about promotion
Students sometimes funk challenging courses by dropping them early

definitions: guide or channel something through or as if through a funnel
examples: The crowd funneled through the narrow stadium entrance slowly
The company funnels all customer complaints through one department

definitions: grant a temporary leave of absence to an employee especially due to special circumstances
examples: The company furloughed half its workforce during the economic downturn
Prison officials furloughed the inmate to attend his mother's funeral

definitions: provide a house or room with furniture and fittings
supply someone with something or provide something that is needed
examples: They furnished their new apartment with modern minimalist pieces
The landlord furnished the rental property with basic appliances
The witness furnished police with crucial evidence for the case
The library furnishes students with access to thousands of journals

definitions: make a long narrow groove or channel in the ground or surface
examples: The farmer furrowed the field in preparation for planting corn
Years of worry had furrowed his brow with deep lines

definitions: help the progress or development of something or someone
examples: She took additional courses to further her career in marketing
The new funding will further research into renewable energy sources

definitions: join or blend things together to form a single entity especially by melting
examples: The welder fused the metal pieces together creating a strong joint
High temperatures fused the sand into glass over millions of years

definitions: talk at length in an idle or gossipy way
examples: The neighbors gabbed over the fence for hours every afternoon
Coworkers gabbed about weekend plans during their lunch break

definitions: go around from one place to another in pursuit of pleasure or entertainment
examples: She gadded about town shopping and visiting friends all day
Instead of studying he gadded around campus socializing constantly

definitions: put something in or over a person's mouth to prevent speaking
choke or retch as if about to vomit
examples: The kidnappers gagged their victim to prevent him calling for help
The court order gagged the press from reporting sensitive details
The terrible smell made everyone gag as they entered the room
She gagged on the bitter medicine but managed to swallow it

definitions: offer something valuable as a guarantee of good faith
examples: Knights would gage their armor as pledge before a tournament
He gaged his watch to secure the informal loan

definitions: make someone feel irritated or resentful by unfair treatment
examples: It galled her that less qualified people received promotions first
His arrogant attitude galled everyone who worked with him

definitions: go at the fastest pace of a horse or similar animal
examples: The horse galloped across the field with its mane flying
Wild horses galloped away when they sensed approaching danger

definitions: play games of chance for money or bet on uncertain outcomes
take risky action hoping for a desired result
examples: He gambled his savings at the casino and lost everything
She gambles on horse races occasionally for entertainment
The company gambled on launching the product without market research
Farmers gamble on weather conditions when planting their crops

definitions: undergo decay of body tissue due to obstructed blood supply or infection
examples: The wound gangrened because proper medical treatment was delayed too long
Without antibiotics the infected toe began to gangrene rapidly

definitions: put someone in prison as lawful punishment
examples: The judge gaoled the thief for two years after conviction
They gaoled political prisoners without proper trials during wartime

definitions: stare with mouth open wide in amazement or wonder
examples: Tourists gaped at the magnificent view from the mountain top
Children gaped at the circus performers doing dangerous stunts

definitions: dress in distinctive clothes especially of a particular kind
examples: The actors garbed themselves in period costumes for the play
Monks garb themselves in simple robes as sign of humility

definitions: decorate with a wreath of flowers and leaves
examples: They garlanded the wedding venue with fresh roses and ivy
Winners were garlanded with flower wreaths at the ancient games

definitions: gather or collect something especially information or approval
examples: The film garnered critical acclaim at international festivals
She garnered support from colleagues for her innovative proposal

definitions: decorate or embellish food for presentation
examples: The chef garnished each plate with fresh herbs and edible flowers
She garnished the cocktails with lime wedges and mint leaves

definitions: provide a place with troops for defense
examples: The army garrisoned the border town to prevent enemy invasion
They garrisoned the fort with five hundred soldiers

definitions: make a long deep slash cut or wound
examples: He gashed his hand on broken glass while cleaning up
The rock gashed a hole in the ship's hull during the storm

definitions: estimate or determine the magnitude amount or volume of something
examples: Engineers gauge the water pressure before installing new pipes
It's difficult to gauge public opinion without conducting proper surveys

definitions: announce or publish something in an official gazette
examples: The government gazetted the new regulations in the official publication
Military promotions were gazetted in the defense ministry bulletin

definitions: command a horse to go faster or turn to the right
examples: The farmer geed the horses to turn right at the crossroads
She geed the team of horses to speed up their pace

definitions: be enthusiastically interested in and knowledgeable about a particular subject
examples: He geeks out over vintage computers and old programming languages
She geeks about astronomy and can name every constellation

definitions: form into a gel or jelly-like substance
come together smoothly and work well as a group
examples: The mixture will gel after being refrigerated for two hours
Hair products gel when exposed to air and movement
The new team took time to gel but eventually worked perfectly
Their different skills gelled to create an effective partnership
